statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Harvard 50, Princeton 43
article.story: BOSTON (AP) -- Drew Housman scored 20 points to help Harvard defeat Princeton 50-43 in Ivy League action Saturday. Harvard held Princeton to one field goal in the first nine minutes of the second and Housman scored 17 points in the final 20 minutes, including 11 in a 15-2 Crimson run that gave them their first lead since early in the first half. Marcus Schroeder paced the Tigers (11-14, 2-9 Ivy League) with 10 points. Justin Conway led both teams in rebounding with 8 while scoring nine points for Princeton. Harvard (11-15, 4-8) shot 16 percent from the field in the opening half but blistered the nets making 13 of 19 shots from the floor in the final half. Evan Harris grabbed seven rebounds for the Crimson, who outrebounded Princeton 30-27. Harvard was 18 of 20 from the free throw line to seven of eight for Princeton. The Tigers held Harvard to 3 of 19 from the field in the first and used a 8-2 run during the final 9:26 of the first half to take a 21-12 lead at intermission. Schroeder paced the Princeton attack with five points while Harris led both teams in scoring with six points. Harvard opened the second half by going on a 15-2 run and took a 27-23 lead with 11:57 on the clock on a Housman layup. Brad Unger's layup with 9:08 left capped a 6-2 Harvard run that extended their lead to 31-25. Princeton answered with a 6-2 run cutting the Crimson lead to 36-33, following a pair of free throws by Conway, with 3:55 remaining. Harvard held the Tigers to four field goals in the final three minutes to break their six game losing streak.
